column2: But when she knew that Edward was alive, and had come back, sobbed Dot, now speaking for herself, as she had burned to do, all through this narrative; "and when she knew his purpose, she advised him by all means to keep his secret close; for his old friend John Peerybingle was much too open in his nature, and too clumsy in all artifice--being a clumsy man in general," said Dot, half laughing and half crying--"to keep it for him.
column3: But when she knew that Edward was alive, and had come back, sobbed Dot, now speaking for herself, as she had burned to do, all through this narrative; "and when she knew his purpose, she advised him by all means to keep his secret close; for his old friend john Peerybingle was much too open in his nature, and too clumsy in all artifice-being a clumsy man in general," said Dot, half laughing and half crying-"to keep it for him.

column2: And when she--that's me, John," sobbed the little woman--"told him all, and how his sweetheart had believed him to be dead; and how she had at last been over-persuaded by her mother into a marriage which the silly, dear old thing called advantageous; and when she--that's me again, John--told him they were not yet married (though close upon it), and that it would be nothing but a sacrifice if it went on, for there was no love on her side; and when he went nearly mad with joy to hear it,--then she--that's me again--said she would go between them, as she had often done before in old times, John, and would sound his sweetheart, and be sure that what she--me again, John--said and thought was right.

column2: Accordingly, Dot went to work to produce such an entertainment as should reflect undying honour on the house and on every one concerned; and, in a very short space of time, she was up to her dimpled elbows in flour, and whitening the Carrier's coat, every time he came near her, by stopping him to give him a kiss. That good fellow washed the greens, and peeled the turnips, and broke the plates, and upset iron pots full of cold water on the fire, and made himself useful in all sorts of ways: while a couple of professional assistants, hastily called in from somewhere in the neighbourhood, as on a point of life or death, ran against each other in all the doorways and round all the corners, and everybody tumbled over Tilly Slowboy and the Baby, everywhere.

column2: Then there was a great Expedition set on foot to go and find out Mrs. Fielding; and to be dismally penitent to that excellent gentlewoman; and to bring her back, by force, if needful, to be happy and forgiving.
column3: Then there was a great Expedition set on foot to go and find out mrs Fielding; and to be dismally penitent to that excellent gentlewoman; and to bring her back, by force, if needful, to be happy and forgiving.

column2: And when the Expedition first discovered her, she would listen to no terms at all, but said, an unspeakable number of times, that ever she should have lived to see the day! and couldn't be got to say anything else, except "Now carry me to the grave": which seemed absurd, on account of her not being dead, or anything at all like it.
column3: And when the Expedition first discovered her, she would listen to no terms at all, but said, an unspeakable number of times, that ever she should have lived to see the day! and couldn't be got to say anything else, except "Now carry me to the grave": which seemed absurd, on account of her not being dead, or anything at all like it.

column2: After a time she lapsed into a state of dreadful calmness, and observed that, when that unfortunate train of circumstances had occurred in the Indigo Trade, she had foreseen that she would be exposed, during her whole life, to every species of insult and contumely; and that she was glad to find it was the case; and begged they wouldn't trouble themselves about her,--for what was she?--oh dear! a nobody!--but would forget that such a being lived, and would take their course in life without her.
column3: After a time she lapsed into a state of dreadful calmness, and observed that, when that unfortunate train of circumstances had occurred in the Indigo Trade, she had foreseen that she would be exposed, during her whole life, to every species of insult and contumely; and that she was glad to find it was the case; and begged they wouldn't trouble themselves about her,--for what was she?--oh dear! a nobody!--but would forget that such a being lived, and would take their course in life without her.

column2: From this bitterly sarcastic mood she passed into an angry one, in which she gave vent to the remarkable expression that the worm would turn if trodden on; and, after that, she yielded to a soft regret, and said, if they had only given her their confidence, what might she not have had it in her power to suggest!
column3: From this bitterly sarcastic mood she passed into an angry one, in which she gave vent to the remarkable expression that the worm would turn if trodden on; and, after that, she yielded to a soft regret, and said, if they had only given her their confidence, what might she not have had it in her power to suggest!

column2: Taking advantage of this crisis in her feelings, the Expedition embraced her; and she very soon had her gloves on, and was on her way to John Peerybingle's in a state of unimpeachable gentility; with a paper parcel at her side containing a cap of state, almost as tall, and quite as stiff, as a mitre.
column3: Taking advantage of this crisis in her feelings, the Expedition embraced her; and she very soon had her gloves on, and was on her way to john Peerybingle's in a state of unimpeachable gentility; with a paper parcel at her side containing a cap of state, almost as tall, and quite as stiff, as a mitre.

column2: Then, there were Dot's father and mother to come in another little chaise; and they were behind their time; and fears were entertained; and there was much looking out for them down the road; and Mrs. Fielding always would look in the wrong and morally impossible direction; and, being apprised thereof, hoped she might take the liberty of looking where she pleased.
column3: Then, there were Dot's father and mother to come in another little chaise; and they were behind their time; and fears were entertained; and there was much looking out for them down the road; and mrs Fielding always would look in the wrong and morally impossible direction; and, being apprised thereof, hoped she might take the liberty of looking where she pleased.

column2: At last they came; a chubby little couple, jogging along in a snug and comfortable little way that quite belonged to the Dot family; and Dot and her mother, side by side, were wonderful to see. They were so like each other.
column3: At last they came; a chubby little couple, jogging along in a snug and comfortable little way that quite belonged to the Dot family; and Dot and her mother, side by side, were wonderful to see. They were so like each other.

column2: Then Dot's mother had to renew her acquaintance with May's mother; and May's mother always stood on her gentility; and Dot's mother never stood on anything but her active little feet.
column3: Then Dot's mother had to renew her acquaintance with May's mother; and May's mother always stood on her gentility; and Dot's mother never stood on anything but her active little feet.

column2: And old Dot--so to call Dot's father, I forgot it wasn't his right name, but never mind--took liberties, and shook hands at first sight, and seemed to think a cap but so much starch and muslin, and didn't defer himself at all to the Indigo Trade, but said there was no help for it now; and, in Mrs. Fielding's summing up, was a good-natured kind of man--but coarse, my dear.
column3: And old Dot-so to call Dot's father, I forgot it wasn't his right name, but never mind-took liberties, and shook hands at first sight, and seemed to think a cap but so much starch and muslin, and didn't defer himself at all to the Indigo Trade, but said there was no help for it now; and, in mrs Fielding's summing up, was a good-natured kind of man-but coarse, my dear.

column2: I wouldn't have missed Dot, doing the honours in her wedding-gown, my benison on her bright face! for any money.
column3: I wouldn't have missed Dot, doing the honours in her wedding gown, my benison on her bright face! for any money.

column3: No! nor the good Carrier, so jovial and so ruddy, at the bottom of the table.

column2: Nor the brown, fresh sailor-fellow, and his handsome wife.
column3: Nor the brown, fresh sailor fellow, and his handsome wife.

column2: Nor any one among them.
column3: Nor any one among them.

column2: To have missed the dinner would have been to miss as jolly and as stout a meal as man need eat; and to have missed the overflowing cups in which they drank The Wedding Day would have been the greatest miss of all.
column3: To have missed the dinner would have been to miss as jolly and as stout a meal as man need eat; and to have missed the overflowing cups in which they drank The Wedding Day would have been the greatest miss of all.

column2: After dinner Caleb sang the song about the Sparkling Bowl.
column3: After dinner Caleb sang the song about the Sparkling Bowl.

column2: As I'm a living man, hoping to keep so for a year or two, he sang it through.
column3: As I'm a living man, hoping to keep so for a year or two, he sang it through.

column2: And, by-the-bye, a most unlooked-for incident occurred, just as he finished the last verse.

column2: There was a tap at the door; and a man came staggering in, without saying with your leave, or by your leave, with something heavy on his head.
column3: There was a tap at the door; and a man came staggering in, without saying with your leave, or by your leave, with something heavy on his head.

column2: And, with those words, he walked off.

column2: There was some surprise among the company, as you may imagine.

column2: Mrs. Fielding, being a lady of infinite discernment, suggested that the cake was poisoned, and related a narrative of a cake which, within her knowledge, had turned a seminary for young ladies blue.
column3: mrs Fielding, being a lady of infinite discernment, suggested that the cake was poisoned, and related a narrative of a cake which, within her knowledge, had turned a seminary for young ladies blue.

column2: But she was overruled by acclamation; and the cake was cut by May with much ceremony and rejoicing.
column3: But she was overruled by acclamation; and the cake was cut by May with much ceremony and rejoicing.

column2: I don't think any one had tasted it, when there came another tap at the door, and the same man appeared again, having under his arm a vast brown-paper parcel.

column2: After the delivery of which expressions, he retired again.

column2: The whole party would have experienced great difficulty in finding words for their astonishment, even if they had had ample time to seek them. But they had none at all; for the messenger had scarcely shut the door behind him, when there came another tap, and Tackleton himself walked in.
column3: The whole party would have experienced great difficulty in finding words for their astonishment, even if they had had ample time to seek them. But they had none at all; for the messenger had scarcely shut the door behind him, when there came another tap, and Tackleton himself walked in.

column2: Mrs. Peerybingle! said the toy merchant, hat in hand, "I'm sorry.
column3: mrs Peerybingle! said the toy merchant, hat in hand, "I'm sorry.

column2: I'm more sorry than I was this morning.
column3: I'm more sorry than I was this morning.

column2: I have had time to think of it.
column3: I have had time to think of it.

column2: John Peerybingle!
column3: john Peerybingle!

column2: I am sour by disposition; but I can't help being sweetened, more or less, by coming face to face with such a man as you.
column3: I am sour by disposition; but I can't help being sweetened, more or less, by coming face to face with such a man as you.

column2: Caleb!
column3: Caleb!

column2: This unconscious little nurse gave me a broken hint last night, of which I have found the thread.
column3: This unconscious little nurse gave me a broken hint last night, of which I have found the thread.

column2: I blush to think how easily I might have bound you and your daughter to me, and what a miserable idiot I was when I took her for one!
column3: I blush to think how easily I might have bound you and your daughter to me, and what a miserable idiot I was when I took her for one!

column2: Friends, one and all, my house is very lonely to-night.
column3: Friends, one and all, my house is very lonely to night.

column2: I have not so much as a Cricket on my Hearth.
column3: I have not so much as a Cricket on my Hearth.

column2: I have scared them all away.
column3: I have scared them all away.

column2: Be gracious to me: let me join this happy party!"
column3: Be gracious to me: let me join this happy party!"

column2: He was at home in five minutes.
column3: He was at home in five minutes.

column2: You never saw such a fellow.
column3: You never saw such a fellow.

column2: What _had_ he been doing with himself all his life, never to have known before his great capacity of being jovial?
column3: What underscore had underscore he been doing with himself all his life, never to have known before his great capacity of being jovial?

column2: Or what had the Fairies been doing with him, to have effected such a change?

column2: John! you won't send me home this evening, will you? whispered Dot.
column3: john! you won't send me home this evening, will you? whispered Dot.

column2: He had been very near it, though.

column2: There wanted but one living creature to make the party complete; and, in the twinkling of an eye, there he was, very thirsty with hard running, and engaged in hopeless endeavours to squeeze his head into a narrow pitcher.
column3: There wanted but one living creature to make the party complete; and, in the twinkling of an eye, there he was, very thirsty with hard running, and engaged in hopeless endeavours to squeeze his head into a narrow pitcher.

column2: He had gone with the cart to its journey's end, very much disgusted with the absence of his master, and stupendously rebellious to the Deputy.
column3: He had gone with the cart to its journey's end, very much disgusted with the absence of his master, and stupendously rebellious to the Deputy.

column2: After lingering about the stable for some little time, vainly attempting to incite the old horse to the mutinous act of returning on his own account, he had walked into the taproom, and laid himself down before the fire.
column3: After lingering about the stable for some little time, vainly attempting to incite the old horse to the mutinous act of returning on his own account, he had walked into the taproom, and laid himself down before the fire.

column2: But, suddenly yielding to the conviction that the Deputy was a humbug, and must be abandoned, he had got up again, turned tail, and come home.
column3: But, suddenly yielding to the conviction that the Deputy was a humbug, and must be abandoned, he had got up again, turned tail, and come home.

column2: There was a dance in the evening.
column3: There was a dance in the evening.

column2: With which general mention of that recreation, I should have left it alone, if I had not some reason to suppose that it was quite an original dance, and one of a most uncommon figure.
column3: With which general mention of that recreation, I should have left it alone, if I had not some reason to suppose that it was quite an original dance, and one of a most uncommon figure.

column2: It was formed in an odd way; in this way.
column3: It was formed in an odd way; in this way.

column2: Edward, that sailor-fellow--a good free dashing sort of fellow he was--had been telling them various marvels concerning parrots, and mines, and Mexicans, and gold dust, when all at once he took it in his head to jump up from his seat and propose a dance; for Bertha's harp was there, and she such a hand upon it as you seldom hear.
column3: Edward, that sailor fellow-a good free dashing sort of fellow he was-had been telling them various marvels concerning parrots, and mines, and Mexicans, and gold dust, when all at once he took it in his head to jump up from his seat and propose a dance; for Bertha's harp was there, and she such a hand upon it as you seldom hear.

column2: Dot (sly little piece of affectation when she chose) said her dancing days were over; I think because the Carrier was smoking his pipe, and she liked sitting by him best.
column3: Dot (sly little piece of affectation when she chose) said her dancing days were over; I think because the Carrier was smoking his pipe, and she liked sitting by him best.

column2: Mrs. Fielding had no choice, of course, but to say _her_ dancing days were over, after that; and everybody said the same, except May; May was ready.
column3: mrs Fielding had no choice, of course, but to say underscore her underscore dancing days were over, after that; and everybody said the same, except May; May was ready.

column2: So, May and Edward get up, amid great applause, to dance alone; and Bertha plays her liveliest tune.
column3: So, May and Edward get up, amid great applause, to dance alone; and Bertha plays her liveliest tune.

column2: Well! if you'll believe me, they had not been dancing five minutes, when suddenly the Carrier flings his pipe away, takes Dot round the waist, dashes out into the room, and starts off with her, toe and heel, quite wonderfully.
column3: Well! if you'll believe me, they had not been dancing five minutes, when suddenly the Carrier flings his pipe away, takes Dot round the waist, dashes out into the room, and starts off with her, toe and heel, quite wonderfully.

column2: Tackleton no sooner sees this than he skims across to Mrs. Fielding, takes her round the waist, and follows suit.
column3: Tackleton no sooner sees this than he skims across to mrs Fielding, takes her round the waist, and follows suit.

column2: Old Dot no sooner sees this than up he is, all alive, whisks off Mrs. Dot into the middle of the dance, and is foremost there.
column3: Old Dot no sooner sees this than up he is, all alive, whisks off mrs Dot into the middle of the dance, and is foremost there.

column2: Caleb no sooner sees this than he clutches Tilly Slowboy by both hands, and goes off at score; Miss Slowboy, firm in the belief that diving hotly in among the other couples, and effecting any number of concussions with them, is your only principle of footing it.

column2: But what is this?

column2: Even as I listen to them blithely, and turn towards Dot, for one last glimpse of a little figure very pleasant to me, she and the rest have vanished into air, and I am left alone.

column2: A Cricket sings upon the Hearth; a broken child's toy lies upon the ground: and nothing else remains.
